we want to gather everything there is to know about your data what does it look like what operations
are you running we're going to have a list of inputs and so let us zoom in here because it's

ones what are the ones that are not running at all you need to look through all of this
logs and statistics which is the next thing that we'll talk about and see where are your actual queries running
the more information you can get the more you can describe how you're using your data how your application is
interacting with the data that you are using which collections you are querying the most and which ones you may be
querying across multiple collections when you could be combining them because they're supposed to be queried together
these are the types of questions you want to be answering when you're making sense of your workload
you want to get current and predicted scenarios so if you have an application that runs and you may have some spiky
traffic on certain times you want to collect that type of data you want to get the maximums what is your maximum
traffic look like what are your minimum traffic look like what does average traffic look like these are the
quantifying portions of what your workload means
you may also want to collaborate with a business domain expert so yes us as dev
developers we kind of are in the weeds sometimes and we know what we're working with or we only see the feature or bug
that we're working with sometimes it's always good to speak to a business domain expert so that you can account
for other things that you may not be working with or be not as familiar with or something that you just is out of
your realm of what you've been working on in the last sprint or so these are all great sources of information to help you
make sense of your workload so we take all of these inputs
and out of this initial phase you're going to get some outputs
so the outputs that you will receive are the operations that you run
the queries that you are running the data sizes that you're working with
the assumptions that you're working or the indexes rather the indices that you're working with and the assumptions
that you are making as part of your application out of this entire process and out of
this entire phase once you've made sense of your workload you will have these particular outputs to work with which
will then feed into this next phase so you take all of these pieces of
information you know what you know every query you know the averages you have the qualif the quantifications of how many
times they're running you have your scenarios and now you're going to feed it into this next phase
that next base is to now map out and identify the relationships that are part of your application so having all of

of what is actually being run and what could run so what does mapping out and identifying
relationships look like the first part is to quantify and identify relationships so you all may be
familiar with this type of crow foot notation right we've seen this in a relational database
relational data model before when we're mapping out relationships we have our one-to-one relationships you have our
one-to-many and we have our many-to-many and those are also still found in document databases this is still a very
same way that we're able to model the relationships in document databases
so you want to map those out as well because they do exist and one other thing that we found
because of the way that we are collecting so much more data now and with the rise of how much data we're
able to capture we also have something called one to zillions so this could apply to things like iot
sensors where you're just getting so much information per second or even now when you're dealing with the skill of
amazon or microsoft or netflix anything like that you get petabytes of data per
hour or even per second depending on which team that you're working on the massive amount of data pretty much led
to this additional type of relationship because the existing ones that we had couldn't really fit or capture what that
kind of relationship was like
and adding to that we have the numeral notation of how we note that so if you do have some sort of one to
zillions type of relationship as part of that you'll want to list the minimum amount which is usually zero or
one you'll want to list the likely amount so this is where your averages come in this
is where your current scenarios from the data that you've received from making sense of your workload this is possibly
the number that you can calculate of likely your average use case and then you have your maximum this is your you
know your spikey traffic really top of the line number this is the maximum amount of this particular entity that
you'd be seeing in this relationship
once you've quantified and identified those relationships the next part is to decide whether to link or to embed
and i know some of you who is here thinking what is linking and what's embedding who doesn't know what linking
and embedding is that's fine that's why you're here right so linking and embedding is
not so difficult to understand thinking is something that's going to be very familiar to you if you've already
worked with relational databases so we have a document here in this case it's a
casino and we have some information about this casino what's the name its id
the year that it opened the nicknames that it has etc and linking is literally
getting an id here or a reference and having an additional document
that links to that particular information so we have the id here that says this is the owner and we have the
specific owner information held in a separate document there so it's very similar to adding a foreign key to a
particular entity here and in this case we're putting a link to it in a document
embedding on the other hand is pretty self-explanatory the word itself embedding
justified explains what it's doing so embedding means we will take the information that we need in this case
when we are querying this data about the casino we usually need the name the headquarters and when it was founded and
we're simply going to embed that into the document itself
and that is it that's the difference between linking and embedding so you can think of it as linking is very close to
having a foreign key relationship and then embedding is actually taking the information that you need that might
be stored in a different collection and adding it to the same document you usually want to do this if you have to
query that type of information together so that's when again making sense of your workload if you find that your most
important queries are running so many uh joins which is um can be done in a document database but if you find you're
running so many joins or going off across multiple collections to gather all of that data to bring back to your
application you might want to rethink and get the ones that you need and actually embed it into that single
document because data that is accessed together should stay together and that's how it should be stored
and you'll see that's the information that we've embedded from the owner information so we can just add that as another sub document
so how do we decide to link or embed these are just some general guidelines obviously you have to look at what your
data is like but these are generically what you would want to do so let's first look here if the type of relationship
that you are deciding on is to embed a document in the parent document meaning
in our last example we took some of the information from the owner collection and embedded it into the casino document
with any one-to-one relationships you'll find that you'll have single reads and no joins when you do it in this way same
thing with one-to-many relationships and if you do have many-to-many relationships it's still a single read
because again you're putting all that information together you're putting it in a single document to be able to access it directly in one query you have
no joins however there can be some duplication of information so if you still need that owner collection and you
still have all of that listed out in separate documents but you decide to embed just the subset that you need into
the casino document there is some duplication of information but overall this is okay
especially if you need to access that data together and in the long run it gives your application a better performance boost to have all that
information together in one read
now if we linked in the parent document meaning similar to the foreign key relationship you will find it's it's
quite similar right so one-to-one relationships you'll have smaller reads which could be faster but you'll have
multiple reads you'll have many reads because now you have to access both collections or multiple collections
depending on which things you are linking to and it's the same across all of the relationships the one thing to
keep in mind is if you do have something like a one to zillions relationships you most likely want to uh link everything
because if you're embedding and you have zillions of relationships and you're putting all that extra information in there you're gonna have a bad time so
usually with one to zillions linking is the way to go
so great now we've taken a look at all of the data that we have we have all of the inputs there we've mapped out all of
our entities we've looked at the relationships that are as part of the data that we have had in the first phase
and now the last part is to apply design patterns but there's a caveat see at the
end of phase two you actually have a data model already and this is something that you can use right away so this
third phase is actually an iterate iterative approach meaning if the data model that you have
at the end of phase two is already working and your application is not seeing any type of performance issues or
you don't have you don't have new data that you have to accommodate for then maybe you don't need to apply any design
patterns because the complexity that's added by applying these design patterns may not outweigh the simplicity that you
already have especially if your application is working as intended so keep that in mind that as your application starts to grow and you do
start finding that you're having bottlenecks so you do start finding that there are issues in your application then you can get to phase three you can
go through this methodology again go through phase three and try to apply some of the design patterns that we'll
learn about today there are many design patterns i'm not going to go through all of them i'm already thinking that should be a
separate talk but we will go through a few so what is a design pattern
we've heard about this before we may have seen this in in computer science in general and it's the same thing here in
a data model it's a reusable solution to a commonly recurring problem
and in this case it's a data structuring model that solves a common document data model use case and i say this here
because you know we like to get paired in with the nosql tag but nosql actually
encompasses a whole bunch of other data models nosqls document databases graph databases
key value pairs column wide column stores so that doesn't mean you can apply
these design patterns to any nosql data model these are specifically for
document databases
so what design patterns are available we'll start with the polymorphic one because that kind of
is the basis for most patterns here so the polymorphic pattern
pretty much states and you may have heard of polymorphic before is that the shape of the document can change but
more specifically in the polymorphic pattern let's say you to keep a whole range of documents in a single
collection if those documents have more similar fields than different fields
then it's generically called the polymorphic pattern right you will have some fields that may pertain to only a
particular document depending on a particular field so what does this mean
let's say we have a list of athletes that you're going through and you know in the casino maybe you have some sports
bets and you're looking through all the different athletes and their stats or something in this particular case we have a single
collection of athletes and the first one here we see is kobe bryant the late great kobe bryant and we'll see that we
list the sport the athlete name and the career earnings and those are
the similar fields that we're keeping for all the athletes in this particular collection
if we look at our next document here the next athlete that we're storing is serena williams now i don't think serena
williams plays basketball no i don't think it's been publicly shown anyway but professionally she plays tennis so
in this sense we're going to keep also her sport also her name also her career
earnings but because she plays tennis she has something different she has an event here because the way tennis is
played you may have singles you may have doubles which we'll get to in a moment so that's just the whole point it's a different shape polymorphic means that
this document can exist in the same collection
and more specifically we can even further change serena's document here
because tennis is a different event so here we can actually list the event as yet another array and in this case keep
track of the singles and the career tournament she's one there as well as doubles etc etc so
polymorphic is the basis for most of these design patterns because it relies on the fact that
these documents can change and can exist side by side in the same collection
the next pattern i want to talk about is the attribute pattern so here we see uh
well the attribute pattern let me tell you about it first the attribute battery useful for problems that are based
around really really large numbers of documents and within those documents there's a subset of fields that you want
to query on so in this particular example we have
a list of a movie and their releases let's say we want to search on the
particular release date the problem with searching by release date at least in the way that this has
been modeled is that there's different release dates for different countries so if you were to search on release date
you're going to have to create very many indexes and you're going to have to do it on
each individual release date field that is part of that document so instead of
doing it this way what you can do is apply the attribute pattern
and what we do is we take that particular field that we know we're going to be searching on and we just
apply that as a subset we apply it into an array into this list of movies and
then we are able to query on just the location and the date so not only are
fewer indexes needed because now your indexes look like or this instead of all each individual
separate country would you need to have an index on you would just have to create these two if you have
applied the attribute pattern in this way and because of this queries are also simpler to write because now you don't
have to you know check every single individual release field you can just check this particular location and date
in the subset
lastly one that is very popular and very useful and one you can apply right away is something called the document
versioning pattern so if you're ever faced with the need to maintain previous
versions of documents but you still need to keep a record of what's most current the document versioning pattern is
something that is very very useful so one really good example of this is
something like insurance insurance is the most boring thing ever but i try to make it a little bit more
fun here so in insurance you when you usually you know purchase insurance most
people go with the standard policy right you have your basic things that are there and you start out with whatever
you initially insured so in this case we have a document for bilbo baggins and in
the very first time that he acquired this insurance policy he only has the elven sword that he needs to ensure so
at this moment in time this is the current policy this is how it is right now this is the only thing that he needs
as we continue to grow and let's say bilbo acquires a one ring well now the
current policy needs to change right he not only needs to ensure the elven sword he wants to now add this one very
precious ring to his insurance policy so because we need that current state this
is now going to be revised we see the document versioning here simply a field
that shows what version of that particular document is and to keep track of that we now have to
add another document so now we have to add a separate collection that shows all the revisions that have been made and so
when this change occurs we now have to add called a new policy revision
document you can name it what you want in this case it's the new policy revision document and we have a history
now of what their policy looked like prior so as more things are insured as things are taken away as things change
for the current state of bilbo baggins's insurance the current one will always stay current and you can know that
because you can check the revision and you'll also always have the previous versions by adding a new document to the
policy revision collection so things to note about this it's very
easy to implement even on existing systems because again what's needed here is just one field
that shows what revision it is on and you may have to open up a new collection to keep all of the history
there's no performance impact on the queries on the latest revision because you only have to query against
your current collection the cons of this now though is that it does double the number of writes so
every time it does change remember you have to add another document to the to the policy revision collection or
wherever it is you're storing your history so keep that in mind and then one other thing to keep in mind is you
have to make sure your queries target the correct collection so make sure it always goes to your current one make
sure to name your collection something along the lines of you know you being able to figure out that that
is the current state some other assumptions of the data that
you need to keep in mind for this particular pattern is that usually the documents don't have too many revisions
although in this case this should suffice so insurance it can change over
time but it won't have hundreds of changes or thousands of changes so that is one assumption that is made when
using this particular pattern and there's also not too many documents to version meaning that this is the main
document you'll be working with you won't have multiple documents that hold the same particular information either
you store it all together like before data that's accessed together stayed together you don't split it apart especially when
you apply this particular pattern
and that's just three of the patterns that are available so we spoke about polymorphic
and we spoke about attribute pattern and we spoke about document versioning let me zoom in here so you can see
so document versioning you'll see the use cases that they are usually used for are things like catalogs or content
management personalization and single view applications if we take a look at the attribute pattern that is also used
in catalog or content management and single view patterns and then polymorphic which is the one that we did
speak about is used on the same ones as well as mobile so this is just again a
generic chart of what types of patterns you usually see in different applications because they're the best
use case for those types of applications so these are the other patterns and
you can come and ask me later if you want to know about a particular one there's the bucket pattern which is usually used with iot there's the
outlier pattern pre-allocated computed when you have a lot of things that you're continuously repeatedly computing
and you access all the time you can do that through this pattern and it makes it much faster
but we don't have time for that
and that is it after you apply all of the design patterns that are necessary for your data model you know have a data
model but that's not the end again you continue to go through is through this as your application goes uh and iterates
through the next versions you may find you may need to go through this two times three times you may find that you
need to apply different design patterns if you're finding that you're accessing your data in a different way or if your
workload changes what things used to be the most important queries may no longer be the important queries for whatever
reason so this type of methodology going through each of these phases whenever you find that you're having performance
issues or you need to introduce new data or you're changing what data is important in your application is
something that you can go through and continue to evolve

and finally we find jackpot increases which is going to be a right so there's

on each of these slot machines as no one wins the jackpot grows and grows and grows and grows so in this case we want

have listed the top operations that we're going to run through and now we want to map out and identify these

after looking at the queries that we are running we find that the most important relationships are these we find that we

and this is the listing of those most important entities
so as we start to iterate on our data model we find that we do need to apply some design patterns to this particular
one and we'll go through them super tiny we're going to zoom in let's go so
we find for our slots we want to keep track of the type we
want to keep track of the manufacturer we want to know which location it's in
we want to know the serial number and we want to know the wind chance and the bonuses go over them really quick so it

so we want to know are they a high roller because they get those extra perks we want to know what memberships they have their contact information etc
and so this is what our application or our data model looks like so far
and the first thing you'll see here is we've decided to embed these particular
subsets of information so for slots we have embedded the bonuses information
because we always access that at the same time we want to know when we are looking at this particular slot a bonus
is something we find that we're always looking into when we look at our jackpots we
obviously want to know the participating slots that are part of this jackpot so we choose to embed that in there
for our casinos we have embedded the top slots and for the players we've embedded
embedded their membership and their contact information even though these may be held separately even those these
may be stored in a separate collection for other things for this particular application we've decided to embed them
because as we access them we need all of that information together in a single query
you'll find that we use the document versioning pattern here for slots so we just similarly to the insurance
application we add a revision field because as the slots change as the win
chance changes maybe it is actually being decommissioned because it's an

and similarly to our players sometimes your contact information

peasant who doesn't have a really high membership level so those types of changes are things that don't
usually change too often but are still necessary to keep track of and so in that case we use the the
document versioning pattern for those particular entities
and here we use the attribute pattern for the slots because for most slots we
find that we do query on the particular bonuses we want to analyze what types of
bonuses may be drawing people to those particular slots if we find that the bonuses are more enticing or they're
higher or they're of a particular number we find maybe that has some sort of

and then we have polymorphic so this is our standard slot
document but we can also have one that's like this right we can have one that has different
game bonuses so this one would apply maybe to a slot machine that has different multiple games that you can

could be one of an older slot machine one that has a maintenance log because it has mechanical parts they're not all

of the polymorphic pattern because all of these different types of documents those shaped differently are existing in
the same slots collection
and that is the data model that we have developed for our analytics application
so now that we've gone through the phases now that we've actually applied it to a particular use case
the actually most important question we should ask ourselves is what do we model for do we model for simplicity or do we
model for performance and it depends if we're modeling for simplicity
you're usually a small or early stage app you want to take a look at the size of your document
or your project excuse me and you want to take that into account when you're developing your data model you want to
see the size of your team if it's a single person that is maintaining this particular application then you want to
err on the side of simplicity because you want to make it easier on yourself and maybe you don't need as complex of a
data model to run that application you want to consider if you have shared or hosted resources so how large is the
data that you're working with is your application running at maybe 30 or 100
actions per hour maybe you don't need to apply some design patterns because you don't have that much traffic and
similarly your expected scale so when you take a look at your production logs when you take a look at
your predicted scenarios if you do have larger numbers then
not larger numbers then simplicity is where you would want to go
can we can we zoom no that is there now if you are modeling for performance
you obviously take a look at the opposite right if your project is larger or distributed
then performance is going to be of the utmost importance if you have a larger team or distributed
team if you have more people to be able to help you develop this data model more sources of input so you are sure that
the workload that you're working in with is accurate and you can get those predicted scenarios in uh in order and
quantify and qualify all of them if you have sharded clusters or if you're dealing with multiple regions
again the larger your data size the more likely you're going to need a data model
that is designed for performance and if you have an expected scale that is reaching you know those multiple
